Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Origins of maximum drag reduction in viscoelastic turbulence

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research is focused on the investigation of drag reduction that occurs in turbulent flows and on the reason for its occurrence. While this is a very important fundamental problem in turbulent flows, it also has very significant application areas in energy costs for the transportation of fluids across long distances.

An important technical problem in transporting fluids at high rates or when a solid body travels through a fluid (e.g., an air or naval vessel) is to reduce the fluid drag. In the case of internal flows (i.e., inside conduits), turbulent drag can be dramatically reduced by low levels of polymer or surfactant additives. While this effect is well-known, there is still debate about how it happens. A feature of turbulent drag reduction is the existence of a so-called "maximum drag reduction" (MDR) asymptote. For a given flow geometry at a given pressure drop, there is an asymptotic flow rate that can be achieved through addition of polymers. Changing the concentration, molecular weight or even the chemical structure of the additives has no effect on this asymptotic value -- it is universal. Prior results from the PI's group have showed that viscoelasticity serves to suppress active turbulence and gives rise to a less active, intermittent turbulence state which is termed 'hibernating'. The main hypothesis of the proposal is that this hibernating turbulence state is the one that is responsible for the occurrence of the MDR asymptote. The proposed research will explore turbulent flow of viscoelastic fluids in minimal channel turbulence at high Weissenberg number (the dimensionless Weissenberg number is the ratio of the fluid relaxation time scale to the characteristic time scale of the flow), and in so doing possibly also gain insight regarding near-wall turbulence production in Newtonian flows. The PI would collaborate with a group at the University of Liverpool to perform experiments and he will also investigate the validity of the minimal turbulence cell to large domains via large scale direct numerical simulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit 
 At high flow rates the fluid does not flow smoothly and steadily, but rather displays turbulence, during which the flow exhibits fluctuating eddies. In these eddies the work done to pump the fluid is dissipated into heat, increasing the energy cost of transporting fluids over long distance in pipes or propelling a vehicle such as a car, ship or aircraft.  It has long been known that addition of small amounts of polymer molecules to a fluid can dramatically reduce the energy required to pump that fluid in the turbulent flow regime.  The work supported under this grant used theory and computations to gain a fundamental understanding of how the polymer additives are stretched and distorted by the turbulent flow and in turn how the stretched polymers modify the turbulence so as to reduce energy consumption. Key intellectual outcomes of this work include the computational prediction that while polymer additives suppress the usual eddy structures found in turbulent flows near walls, they excite a completely different type of structure -- that is, the polymers have a dual effect on the flow.  Indeed, as the elasticity of the polymers increases, the polymers first completely suppress the turbulent flow, causing to become smooth and steady. (This is called laminar flow.) But at higher elasticity, the polymers re-excite a completely new kind of turbulence. Furthermore, the flow mechanism underlying this new kind of turbulence was traced to a kind of wave  motion that is present in fluids without polymers but that becomes excited rather than damped in their presence. This discovery opens a new direction in understanding turbulence in polymer solutions and other complex non-Newtonian fluids. 


Broader Impacts
It has been estimated that 25% of the energy used to transport fluids is dissipated to heat by turbulence, and this energy corresponds to 5% of annual CO2 emissions.  Therefore, there is a very strong motivation to understand the phenomenon of turbulence and ways by which it might be controlled for reduction of energy consumption. Learning how polymers reduce turbulence may lead to insights for other approaches to turbulence control.  The graduate students trained during the course of this research have gained substantial expertise in broadly applicable tools in pattern analysis and scientific computing as well as contributing substantially to the advancement of the field of non-Newtonian fluid mechanics.  These skills contribute substantially to US technological leadership. 


The principal investigar of this grant has co-developed a undergraduate engineering course ``Chemical Engineering in the Community'' that he continues to develope and participate in. In this course, undergraduate students develop age-appropriate fluid-mechanics-based educational activities for K-12 kids and go to various venues including the Boys and Girls Club of Dane County and the Wisconsin Science Festivla, and local schools, to perform the activities with the kids. This project has run two times over the duration of this grant and will continue in future semesters.
